bestBHT.bht: In the last days, during the days of the Messiah, God will pour out His Spirit abundantly on all flesh without distinction of age, sex, or rank. This outpouring signifies a significant shift in the final dispensation of God's kingdom. It promises a diverse manifestation of the Spirit's gifts, with waking visions and dreams being experienced by the young and the old. This inclusive pouring out of the Spirit marks the humblest classes receiving the Spirit of God, foreshadowing the inclusion of the Gentile world in the covenant promises.

Henry Alford: in the last days is an exposition of the words 'after these things' in the LXX and Hebrew, referring it to the days of the Messiah."
saith God does not occur in the verse of Joel, but at the beginning of the whole passage, ver. 12, and is supplied by Peter here.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: In the last days—meaning, the days of the Messiah... constituting the final dispensation of God's kingdom on earth.
Pour out of my Spirit—in contrast with the mere drops of all preceding time.
Sons... daughters... young men... old men... servants... handmaidens—without distinction of sex, age, or rank.
Albert Barnes: The last days, or the closing period of the world, were the days of the Messiah.
The promise that he would pour out his Spirit means that he would, in the time of the Messiah, impart a large measure of those influences which it was his special province to communicate to people.
The will of God in former times was communicated to the prophets in various ways. One was by visions, and hence one of the most usual names of the prophets was seers.
Marvin Vincent: All flesh. Without distinction of age, sex, or condition.
Dream dreams [ενυπνια ενυπνιασθησονται]. The best texts read ejnupnioiv, with dreams.
John Calvin: For, when God will briefly promise salvation to his people, he affirmeth that he will give them his Spirit. Hereupon it followeth that we can obtain no good things until we have the Spirit given us.
And truly it is, as it were, the key which openeth unto us the door, that we may enter into all the treasures of spiritual good things; and that we may also have entrance into the kingdom of God.

And as for us, let us know that the same is spoken to us at this day which was then spoken to the Jews. For although those visible graces of the Spirit be ceased, yet God hath not withdrawn his Spirit from his Church.
Philip Schaff: The age of Messiah is so termed in 1 John 2:18: ‘Little children, it is the last time.’
He conceived a time when the Spirit of the Lord should descend on no priestly or prophet caste merely, but on every faithful and true Israelite.
It was his first preparation for the great work of his noble life the admission of the vast Gentile world to an equal share in the covenant promises.
Archibald T. Robertson: I will pour forth... This verb means to pour out."
The humblest classes will receive the Spirit of God."
The variety in the manifestations of the Spirit.
John Gill: I will pour out my Spirit upon all flesh... and your sons and your daughters shall prophesy.
By the Spirit is meant the gifts of the Spirit... the abundance and great plenty of the gifts and graces of the Spirit bestowed.
The apostles were young men, on whom the Spirit was poured; and the thing was the more wonderful that so it should be, than if they had been old men.
John Wesley: The times of the Messiah are frequently called the last days, the Gospel being the last dispensation of Divine grace.
I will pour out of my Spirit — Not on the day of pentecost only, upon all flesh - On persons of every age, sex, and rank.

And your young men shall see visions — In young men the outward sense, are most vigorous, and the bodily strength is entire, whereby they are best qualified to sustain the shock which usually attends the visions of God. In old men the internal senses are most vigorous, suited to divine dreams. Not that the old are wholly excluded from the former, nor the young from the latter.

bhtAttempts.bht: In the last days, referring to the days of the Messiah, God will pour out His Spirit in abundance. This outpouring will be for all people, without distinction of age, sex, or rank. It will manifest through various means such as waking visions and dreams. This pouring out of the Spirit on all flesh signifies a shift in God's kingdom, where even the humblest classes will receive His Spirit. The age of the Messiah, termed the last days, marks the inclusion of the Gentile world in the covenant promises. Through this, the Spirit becomes the key to unlocking all the treasures of spiritual blessings and access to the kingdom of God.

In the last days, God will pour out His Spirit abundantly on all people, without distinction of age, sex, or rank. This outpouring signifies a fundamental shift in God's kingdom during the days of the Messiah. The Spirit's manifestation will include waking visions and dreams, which will be experienced by the young and the old. This pouring out of the Spirit marks a significant preparation, allowing the inclusion of the Gentile world in the covenant promises. Through this outpouring, the Spirit becomes the key to accessing spiritual blessings and the kingdom of God.

In the last days, God will pour forth His Spirit abundantly on all flesh, without distinction. This outpouring represents a significant shift in the final dispensation of God's kingdom, during the days of the Messiah. It is a promise of the diverse manifestations and gifts of the Spirit. The Spirit will be bestowed upon sons, daughters, young men, old men, servants, and handmaidens alike. This inclusive pouring out of the Spirit signifies the humblest classes receiving the Spirit of God in a meaningful way.

In the last days, the days of the Messiah, God will pour out His Spirit abundantly on all flesh without distinction, including sons, daughters, young men, old men, servants, and handmaidens. This outpouring signifies a shift in the final dispensation of God's kingdom, where the humblest classes will receive the diverse manifestations and gifts of the Spirit. The pouring out of the Spirit will result in waking visions and dreams, empowering both the young and the old to experience divine revelation. This signifies the inclusion of all people in the covenant promises.

In the last days, during the days of the Messiah, God will pour out His Spirit abundantly on all flesh without distinction of age, sex, or rank. This outpouring signifies a significant shift in the final dispensation of God's kingdom. It promises a diverse manifestation of the Spirit's gifts, with waking visions and dreams being experienced by the young and the old. This inclusive pouring out of the Spirit marks the humblest classes receiving the Spirit of God, foreshadowing the inclusion of the Gentile world in the covenant promises.
